Dear Ms. Brewer:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Communication
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4124
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a written policy
Description regarding communication that ensures that a child is able
to communicate with family and friends in a manner
appropriate to the child’s functioning and consistent with
the child’s treatment plan and security level.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was denied the ability to call her mother and caseworker
by facility staff.
Investigation Email communication occurred with the Complainant on
03/08/2024 and she had no additional information to provide.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed during a previously
scheduled announced visit to the facility on 03/07/2024. She
confirmed the policy as of that date of the facility for facilitating
phone calls with youth and approved contacts. The Chief
Administrator stated there were specific days of the week
respectively reserved for phone contact with caseworkers and
families. Outside of those days she stated there were times when
a youth would ask staff if they could call their caseworker or family
members and staff had been instructed by facility leadership to not
allow them, but they would alert the caseworker that youth wanted
a phone call. She could not confirm why this policy was not
included in what had previously been provided to Licensing for
review, or when this policy was instituted prior to her time in the
Chief Administrator position. The Chief Administrator described
some motivation behind the facility policy, including the common
occurrence that contact with family was triggering for youth.
Youth A was interviewed during a previously scheduled
announced visit to the facility on 03/07/2024. She stated she had
been placed at the facility for a few weeks. Youth A described her
experience with communication outside of the program. She
recalled her first couple of weeks at the program she was able to
make phone calls to those on her approved contact list at any
time. Youth A stated since this time she was told she could only
make outgoing calls to her caseworker on Mondays or
Wednesdays, and her family only on the weekends. Youth A
2

could not recall which specific staff this involved. Youth A recalled
a specific instance when she was feeling anxious, and she wanted
to call her mother. Youth A stated this occurred on a Tuesday,
and the Chief Administrator informed her she could not call her
mother that day. Youth A stated she eventually had a brief AWOL
from the facility that day, and she believed not being able to call
her mother attributed to that. In addition, Youth A stated the day
prior, which was Wednesday 03/06/2024, she requested to staff
that she be able to call her caseworker. Youth A reported the staff
working (which she could not recall) stated to her that her phone
list could not be found at this time, and she could not make a
phone call this day until it was located.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth A’s foster care case was reviewed, and it was noted
that she was placed at the facility on 02/25/2024.
• Policies & procedures provided by the facility were
reviewed:
o The “Resident Handbook” that was current as of the
time of this investigation was reviewed. This was
last revised on 06/18/2023. In this policy the
“Communications” section covers phone calls that
youth can make. There were no specific policies
listed regarding when youth can make phone calls
out to caseworkers or family. It was stated that
“Families and friends are encouraged to call during
schedule times” but did not specify what times to
which that referred.
o During the previously scheduled face-to-face visit to
the facility on 03/07/2024 it was confirmed the
program had more specific policy regarding youth
making phone calls. At that time the facility allowed
youth to make outgoing phone calls to pre-approved
contacts on Mondays and Wednesdays during
certain times after the school day. Incoming phone
calls were allowed at any time.
▪ At the time of initiation of this investigation
this updated policy had not been provided to
Licensing for review or feedback.
• The current contract the facility holds with DHHS
references a requirement that the facility “arrange for the
child to make immediate phone contact (within two hours of
placement) with their parents and/or siblings whenever
reasonably possible.”
3

Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed there was evidence found that the policy of the facility
regarding contact with family and caseworkers was too restrictive,
violating the rule cited.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility is advised to revise their phone call policies for
youth to allow for more access to outgoing calls to
caseworkers, service providers and families to allow for the
best communication, case management and treatment of
the youth.
• Staff should be trained in the location of essential
information such as approved contacts and phone numbers
and the program should ensure that the information is
easily available at any given time.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Based on the findings in this report a CAP is required.
Per SIR #2024C0001037SI, a 1st provisional license is recommended.
